item.title: Apple, Amazon, Facebook, Google defend firms against calls for break-up
item.description: US lawmakers are considering tougher regulation of the firms, which critics say are too powerful.

item.title: Wiley apology for tweets 'that looked anti-Semitic' after Twitter ban
item.description: The grime artist apologises for "generalising" Jewish people after being banned from social media.

item.title: MI6: Richard Moore named as new head of Secret Intelligence Service
item.description: Mr Moore will take over in the autumn and is described as having the "perfect blend of experience".

item.title: Mystery of origin of Stonehenge megaliths solved
item.description: Archaeologists have pinpointed the source of the stones to an area 15 miles north of the site.

item.title: Coronavirus: Airport testing and a royal lockdown
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus outbreak this Wednesday evening.

item.title: Madeleine McCann: Suspect Christian B rented allotment, neighbour says
item.description: An allotment owner in Germany claims the main suspect rented the plot that was searched by police.

item.title: Travel bosses demand end to blanket quarantine
item.description: Regional travel corridors would allow quarantine-free visits to some areas of Spain, they tell the PM.

item.title: Terror after girl falls 100ft down Llanberis waterfall
item.description: Six-year-old Phoebe was washed over the top and plunged more than 100ft (30m).

item.title: Trump's tweets about masks 'not helpful', says Dr Fauci
item.description: The US top infectious disease expert disputes claims on social media made by the president.

item.title: Boeing to end 747 production and warns of job cuts
item.description: The US planemaker said redundancies may be deeper than the 10% reduction already announced.

item.title: Meghan asks court to keep identities of friends secret in legal action
item.description: The duchess says friends who spoke anonymously to a US magazine last year have a "right to privacy".

item.title: Pop star Rina Sawayama 'not British enough' to enter UK music awards
item.description: British-Japanese artist Rina Sawayama says she's been ruled ineligible for major UK music awards.

item.title: Prince William delivers curry to Peter Crouch at Kensington Palace
item.description: Prince William takes a special delivery for That Peter Crouch Podcast at Kensington Palace.

item.title: Coronavirus: Scaled back Hajj pilgrimage begins
item.description: Muslims are beginning a scaled back annual Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Endangered tigers making a 'remarkable' comeback
item.description: Figures suggest India, China, Nepal, Russia and Bhutan have seen rising tiger numbers.

item.title: Coronavirus: The car boot sale that's back on its feet
item.description: How does a post-lockdown rummage work and what have people made of the changes?

item.title: Bringing Mars back to Earth
item.description: An audacious mission to bring rock samples from Mars back to Earth is about to begin - find out more with our illustrated guide

item.title: Coronavirus: 'We've paid for Spain trip so we may as well go'
item.description: Travellers are determined to take their holidays to Spain regardless of the changing travel advice since a rise of coronavirus cases there.

item.title: Emmy Awards 2020: Paul Mescal credits Normal People nomination to co-star
item.description: Paul Mescal says he was only shortlisted due to the "extraordinary talent" of Daisy Edgar-Jones.

item.title: Guinness World Record: Women circumnavigate world on tandem bicycle
item.description: Cat Dixon and Raz Marsden achieved it in 263 days, beating the record of 281 days.

item.title: Hajj 2020: 'It would have been my solace'
item.description: In the past year, Anisa lost her mother, her job and her house and had hoped Hajj would help her find solace.

item.title: Elmhurst Ballet School helping young dancers with body image
item.description: The ballet world is competitive and the pressure on young dancers to achieve the "perfect physique" is high.

item.title: Climate change: Coastal erosion 'to threaten more Australian homes'
item.description: See the damage done by waves – and the problem will only get worse with climate change, experts say.

item.title: Pre-colonial communities’ history of gender fluidity
item.description: The BBC spoke to three people from cultures that have a long history of gender fluidity.

item.title: Coronavirus on campus: 'We already lost prom and graduation...'
item.description: The BBC spoke to three students about the uncertainty of schools reopening in the age of Covid-19.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'Mum died while we were at dad's funeral'
item.description: John and Mary Boxer died within 16 days of each other, weeks before their 60th wedding anniversary.

item.title: Spain quarantine rules: The businesses fearing for their futures
item.description: Spain's struggling tourist businesses say the UK's new quarantine rules may drive them off the edge.

item.title: UK holidays: Nothing left or 'it's a ridiculous price'
item.description: Holiday rental firms and hotels are reporting unprecedented demand with accommodation filling up fast.

item.title: Saudi Hajj coronavirus curbs mean 'no work, no salary, nothing'
item.description: Covid-19 has hit the annual Hajj and with no international pilgrims, many firms both in Saudi and abroad are suffering.

item.title: 'Coronavirus has delayed my career prospects'
item.description: The government can retrain and support people, but are there the jobs to provide employment?

item.title: Malta: The island hoping to be 2020's festival hotspot
item.description: Malta is set to host four festivals over the coming months after British events were cancelled.

item.title: International students turn to food banks in lockdown
item.description: Hundreds of international students are unable afford fees, food or rent as funds dry up due to virus.

item.title: Will a £50 bike repair voucher get Wellingborough cycling?
item.description: Can a government cycling initiative work in the town where people cycle the least?

item.title: Hydroxychloroquine: Why a video promoted by Trump was pulled on social media
item.description: The anti-malaria drug promoted by President Trump as a treatment for Covid-19 is again at the centre of a political storm.

item.title: Joshua will fight 'anywhere, anytime'... even in my garden - Hearn
item.description: World heavyweight champion Anthony Joshua will fight "anytime, anywhere" according to his promoter Eddie Hearn.

item.title: GB's Bates may consider leg amputation to continue international career
item.description: GB wheelchair basketball player George Bates says he may have to consider having his leg amputated to continue playing.

item.title: England name unchanged squad for first Test with Pakistan
item.description: England name an unchanged 14-man squad for the first of three Tests against Pakistan, which begins on 5 August at Old Trafford.

item.title: Premier League predictions 2019-20: How accurate were the BBC Sport pundits?
item.description: Twenty-four BBC pundits predicted who would win the 2019-20 Premier League title and finish in the top four - how did they get on?

item.title: Coronavirus: Why isn't the UK testing travellers on arrival?
item.description: Some countries offer a choice - get tested or go into quarantine. Should the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus: Where can I go on holiday? A guide to destinations
item.description: As people in the UK get the green light to go abroad again, here's a look at what's in store for travellers.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is shielding?
item.description: As restrictions lift, you might feel anxious about how to stay safe. Here's what experts advise.

item.title: Coronavirus pandemic: Tracking the global outbreak
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the respiratory virus has spread around the world and how it is being dealt with.

item.title: Coronavirus: How can I use the 'eat out to help out scheme'?
item.description: Thousands of venues will take part in a discounting scheme to help boost the hospitality industry.

item.title: Coronavirus vaccine: How close are we and who will get it?
item.description: The BBC looks at the work needed to create a coronavirus vaccine and when one might be ready.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: England will follow Scotland by making face coverings compulsory in shops.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK's travel rules and which countries can you visit?
item.description: New agreements mean people entering the UK from certain countries will not have to quarantine.

item.title: Coronavirus: When I come back from Spain, will I get paid if I self-isolate?
item.description: The 14-day quarantine on travellers arriving from Spain has caused "uncertainty and confusion".

item.title: Step-by-step guide to making your own face mask
item.description: Our guide to different types of face coverings and step-by-step instructions on how to make them.

item.description: Questions about how a vaccine might work and other coronavirus topics.

item.title: Coronavirus: False and misleading claims about vaccines debunked

item.title: Coronavirus: How are indoor gyms and pools going to open?
item.description: As lockdown eases in England, more activities are being allowed but how are customers being kept safe?

item.title: Working from home: How to cut your tax bill
item.description: Home workers can claim tax allowances for their lighting, heating and other expenses.

item.title: Coronavirus vaccine: When will we have one?
item.description: About 200 groups of medical researchers around the world are working on a vaccine for Covid-19.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'Deadly masks' claims debunked
item.description: The BBC's anti-disinformation team has been investigating misleading health claims about wearing face coverings.

item.title: How not to wear a face mask
item.description: New rules mean face coverings are now mandatory in England in all shops.

item.title: What is redundancy, who can be made redundant and what are my rights?
item.description: As thousands of job losses owing to coronavirus are announced, here is a guide to your financial entitlements.

item.title: Coronavirus cure: What progress are we making on treatments?
item.description: Teams around the world are looking into medicines for Covid-19 and scientists are starting to discover what works.

item.title: Coronavirus: A user's guide to wearing a face mask to the shops
item.description: From stopping your glasses fogging up to washing techniques, here's what you need to know.

item.title: How to stop your glasses steaming up with a face mask on
item.description: Three simple tips to stop your glasses fogging up while you shop with a mask or face covering on.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the care home visiting rules in England?
item.description: New guidance gives hope to relatives wanting to visit care homes.

item.title: Coronavirus: Young people on benefits double in lockdown
item.description: Experts fear it may take up to four years for youth unemployment to recover from the pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are more local lockdowns likely in England?
item.description: Oldham is the latest area to take local action to prevent the spread of coronavirus.

item.title: Does getting coronavirus make you immune?
item.description: What you need to know about how the immune system works.

item.description: Social distancing and lockdown rules are changing in England - but what can you now do?

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk on transport?
item.description: People are being asked to return to work, meaning public transport could become more crowded.

item.title: The dying teenager who wanted world peace (and love)
item.description: An American teen with cancer went to Moscow in 1988 hoping to meet Gorbachev and rid the world of nukes.
